displaytitle: War Views: A Dead Rebel Soldier, as he lay on the foot passage in the Trenches of Fort Mahone, called by the Soldiers "Fort Damnation"
creditline: Gift of David B. Long in honor of Joe Cavallaro
markings:
Stamped on left: Photographic History

Stamped on right: The War for the Union

Stamped below: Entered according to Act of Congress in the year 1865 by E. & H.T. Anthony & Co. in the Clerk's Office of the Distric Court of the U.S. for the So. District of New York.

Typed on paper adhered to verso: WAR VIEWS. | A Dead Rebel Soldier, as he lay on the foot passage in the Trenches of Fort | Mahone, called by Soldiers "Fort Damnation." Part of a broken Musket and Bayonet stuck in the | bank. The marks and spots on his face are blood oozing from the wound in his head. This View was | taken the morning after the storming of Petersburg, Va., April 2nd, 1865. | No. 3178. | Copyright Secured. | Published by E. & H.T. Anthony & Co., | American and Foreign Stereoscopic Emporium, 501 Broadway, New-York.

titles.title: War Views: A Dead Rebel Soldier, as he lay on the foot passage in the Trenches of Fort Mahone, called by the Soldiers "Fort Damnation"

makers.displaymaker: Published by E. and H. T. Anthony, active 1852–1901, New York

texts.textentryhtml:
Undeterred by dangerous circumstances and motivated by commercial success, Thomas C. Roche was among the few battlefield photographers to remain near the Petersburg, Virginia, front during the last days of the Civil War, producing one of the most extensive series of battlefield views. Many of his photographs are stereographs, a format that places two images taken at slightly different angles side by side on a single card. When viewed through a binocular device called a stereoscope, the two images coalesce into one, producing an illusion of three-dimensionality. Widely distributed to convey narratives related to the recent war, these stereographs serve as examples of photography’s role as a tool of mass communication.

As part of Roche’s War Views series, "Fort Damnation" shows a dead Confederate soldier lying along the foot passage of the trenches, which diagonally cuts through the composition. While the body appears intact, the blood stain around his nose and mouth reminds the viewer of the cruel reality of the war. The soldier’s face is calm, and his arms are crossed over his stomach—a pose that he could not have assumed naturally upon his death. Thomas Roche, like many other Civil War photographers, did not simply photograph the scenes he found but rather manipulated bodies and objects for aesthetic effect. Like “Fort Hell” (2018-52), this image recalls the conventions of antebellum post-mortem photography, quite popular among those who could afford it.
Purchased by David B. Long; given to the Princeton University Art Museum, 2018.

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Princeton University Art Museum 2018," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 77/78 (2017-18)
